CN and CP exceed their Maximum Grain Revenue Entitlements for Crop Year -2017 The Canadian Transportation Agency (CTA) ruled that revenues of the Canadian National Railway Company (CN) and the Canadian Pacific Railway Company (CP) have exceeded their Maximum grain revenue entitlements for crop year -2017. - CN’s grain revenue of $808,213,784 was $5,773,741 above its entitlement of $802,440,043. - CP's grain revenue of $725,457,448 was $1,078, above its entitlement of $724,378,501. CN and CP now have days to pay the amount by which they exceeded their -2017 revenue entitlements, in addition to a five percent penalty of $288,687 for CN and $53,947 for CP. Regulations stipulate that such payments must be made to the Western Grains Research Foundation, a farmer-financed and directed organization set up to fund research that benefits Prairie farmers. In the -2017 crop year, ,196,615 tonnes of Western grain were moved—6.9 percent more than the volume moved during the previous crop year. The average length of haul of miles was two miles, or percent, higher than the previous crop year.

Is the "higher cost" of operating an offered Canadian ship considered sufficient evidence that it is not economically suitable? Not exactly. This is part of the pleadings process. More information on this process is available in Part of our Guidelines at 8.

link_name: Inspections, investigations and compliance verifications | Canadian Transportation Agency
status_message_cleaned: The Agency's enforcement powers are set out in legislation and regulation. These enforcement powers include: • ensuring the aircraft are insured and authorized under licence by Transport Canada, • verification of flight records, tickets, invoices and other financial records, • reviewing airline tariffs to ensure they comply with the licence and the law, • ensure that companies have training programs in place to train employees to help persons with disabilities, • ensure that advertisers of air fares comply with all-inclusive air price advertising regulations. For more information about the scope and limits to our enforcement activities, see

The Canadian Transportation Agency is committed to an open and transparent dialogue with Canadians and welcomes a variety of perspectives and opinions. We believe that only by being open to challenge, debate and a free and honest exchange of ideas can we ensure that we are serving Canadians to the best of our ability. However, feedback should be at all times respectful and relevant. It should not include personal attacks or innuendo directed at individual public servants who perform their jobs with dedication and professionalism. For more information, visit .

Did you know? We were pioneers of net neutrality... In , the Board of Railway Commissioners assumed jurisdiction over Canada's early telephone and telegraph toll charges. And in , the Board ruled that the CP, which was operating a telegraph news service, was using discriminatory pricing by charging a higher price for delivering messages that originated with other news services. In the telephone industry, a similar principle was used when Bell Telephone, which had a monopoly in a large part of Canada, was prohibited from providing content-based services. The Board's ruling established a basic principle of Canadian telecommunications - the separation of control of message content from control of transmission - an early eression of what is now called "net neutrality". If you want to know more about our history, check out "At the Heart of Transportation : A moving History" at 1

As Canada has evolved, our responsibilities and services evolved with it. Want to know more? Read At the Heart of Transportation: A Moving History > 1
Canadian Transportation Agency. Small organization, big mandate > -2017 Annual Report >

Our role is to determine if a suitable Canadian ship is available to perform the activity for which a coasting trade licence is being requested. The applicant's role is to provide a clear and complete justification as to why a foreign ship must be imported to perform the proposed activity (if that's the case). The type of information required in this justification depends on the activity proposed. More information is available in section of our Guidelines at .

When a coasting trade licence application is needed to transport passengers, we must determine if a Canadian-registered ship can provide an identical or similar adequate marine service. To do this, we need complete, clear and pertinent information concerning the offered ship and the nature of the proposed activity. To find out what kind of information you must provide in passenger service applications, see section of our Guidelines at

"Travel on a plane, train, bus, or ferry is not just a convenience – it's an essential part of modern life. We should move as close as possible to universal accessibility, with individual accommodation as the failsafe, not the default. We should design for accessibility, build for accessibility, and train staff for accessibility. One in seven Canadians has a disability and this proportion is rising as the population ages, so this is both an ethical and a business imperative." Scott Streiner speaks to the Accessibility Advisory Council on making Canada's national transportation system the most accessible in the world - from principles to practice. 0

"We were returning from Baltimore to Toronto when our flight was cancelled due to poor weather. The airline rebooked us days later because that was their only flight which had availability. Although there was availability on their partner flight, they would not book us on another airline. We could not wait for days to return home, as a result, we purchased new flights. We tried to work with the airline to receive a refund but they refused to offer any compensation. Consequently, we turned to the Canadian Transportation Agency for assistance. Their service was amazing- very thorough, very comprehensive and very attentive. The first contact elained the passenger tariff and our rights as passengers. We took the next step and asked CTA to mediate on our behalf, which fortunately turned out to be a successful exercise. We were very impressed with the support we received and the professionalism of the staff at CTA. It is sad that the state of airline travel in Canada requires an agency such as the CTA but it is reassuring to know that they are there to help ensure passenger rights are met." Marci

link_name: Fly Smart: From point A to point B and home again | Canadian...
status_message_cleaned: Not a light traveller? Did you know? There is no standard rule among airlines about the number of pieces, size or weight of baggage. These amounts are set by each airline, so it is best to check what your airline's rules are in advance. If any of your carry-on or checked baggage exceeds the amounts specified by your airline, you may be required to pay excess baggage charges. Visit our Fly Smart page to find out more about how to prepare for your travels >

If you are planning a trip with an attendant, make sure to contact your airline as early as possible – typically at least hours before departure. You may also want to ask your airline about special fares that could be available for attendants and the conditions for these fares. >

Are you frustrated by your recent air travel eerience? We are eerts at resolving air travel complaints for travel within, to and from Canada. The vast majority of these complaints are resolved quickly, easily and informally through facilitation or mediation. For complex issues, we also offer a court-like process called adjudication, where a panel will make a decision based on the evidence presented >

Each airline has its own terms and conditions in a document called a "tariff". A tariff is a contract that outlines the rights and responsibilities of both the airline and the passenger. To read your airline's tariff, you can visit their ticket counter or go to their website. You can also find a list of links to airline tariffs on our website: As an air traveller, knowing your rights and responsibilities can help you avoid complications and issues during your trip.

Did you know? Our definition of a disability is a health-related problem that limits someone's ability to travel or causes difficulties while travelling. This includes temporary conditions like a broken leg. For more information about accessibility complaints visit >

We are here to resolve complaints about air travel within, to and from Canada. If you have been delayed, bumped, or have lost luggage and can't get help from your airline, you may want to file a complaint using our online form >

We don’t just deal with air travel accessibility. We deal with a wide variety of accessibility complaints including those related to rail, ferry, and bus carriers that cross provincial borders. Even complaints related to rail and bus terminals and airports >

Before you get into full vacation mode… Make sure the airline has your current contact information (email address or phone numbers) so that you can be easily contacted if your flight is delayed, advanced or cancelled. Be sure to check your flight status hours before your flight and then again before leaving for the airport >

Did you know today is National Aviation Day? In we became the first regulatory body in Canada responsible for air travel. In the Board of Transport Commissioners for Canada was merged with the Air Transport Board and the Canadian Maritime Commission to form the Canadian Transport Commission, which took on the mandate to deal with all modes of transportation. Read more about our role in Canadian aviation history >

Travelling with pets Air carriers have different policies regarding the carriage of pets. While some may accept pets as checked baggage or allow them to travel within the cabin with their owners, others may not. Before reserving space for your pet on your flights, ask your air carrier about its pet policy. Also contact the embassy or consulate of your destination country for specific restrictions, as well as the vaccinations and documentation required for pets entering other countries. For the addresses and contact information of diplomatic and consular representatives accredited to Canada, consult the Country Travel Report for your destination at . Find out more at >

link_name: Compliance Report: Accessible Ground Transportation at Airports |...
status_message_cleaned: Today we released our compliance report on accessible ground transportation at airports. The accessible bus, shuttle, taxi and car rental company services are largely accessible at monitored Canadian airports. Of the airports we monitored, airports are fully compliant with the provisions we assessed. All of the remaining airports have committed to becoming fully compliant as contracts with transportation providers are updated. Notable and laudable: most Canadian airports use best practices that go beyond their obligations and demonstrate their commitment to ensuring greater accessibility at their terminals for persons with disabilities. For more information, you can read the compliance report at
